api_activity.description: API events describe general CRUD (Create, Read, Update, Delete) API activities, e.g. (AWS Cloudtrail)
api_activity.caption: API Activity
api_activity.name: api_activity

1.caption: Create
1.description: The API call in the event pertains to a 'create' activity.

2.caption: Read
2.description: The API call in the event pertains to a 'read' activity.

3.caption: Update
3.description: The API call in the event pertains to a 'update' activity.

4.caption: Delete
4.description: The API call in the event pertains to a 'delete' activity.

http_request.description: Details about the underlying http request.

resources.description: Details about resources that were affected by the activity/event.

src_endpoint.description: Details about the source of the activity.

application_lifecycle.description: Application Lifecycle events report installation, removal, start, stop of an application or service.
application_lifecycle.caption: Application Lifecycle
application_lifecycle.name: application_lifecycle

app.description: The application that was affected by the lifecycle event.  This also applies to self-updating application systems.

web_resource_access_activity.caption: Web Resource Access Activity
web_resource_access_activity.description: Web Resource Access Activity events describe successful/failed attempts to access a web resource over HTTP.
web_resource_access_activity.name: web_resource_access_activity

1.caption: Access Grant
1.description: The incoming request has permission to the web resource.

2.caption: Access Deny
2.description: The incoming request does not have permission to the web resource.

3.caption: Access Revoke
3.description: The incoming request's access has been revoked due to security policy enforcements.

4.caption: Access Error
4.description: An error occurred during processing the request.

http_request.description: Details about the underlying HTTP request.

http_response.description: Details about the HTTP response, if available.

proxy.description: Details about the proxy service, if available.

web_resources.description: Details about the resource that is the target of the activity.

src_endpoint.description: Details about the source endpoint of the request.

tls.description: The Transport Layer Security (TLS) attributes, if available.

web_resources_activity.description: Web Resources Activity events describe actions executed on a set of Web Resources.
web_resources_activity.caption: Web Resources Activity
web_resources_activity.name: web_resources_activity

1.caption: Create
1.description: One or more web resources were created.

2.caption: Read
2.description: One or more web resources were read / viewed.

3.caption: Update
3.description: One or more web resources were updated.

4.caption: Delete
4.description: One or more web resources were deleted.

5.caption: Search
5.description: A search was performed on one or more web resources.

6.caption: Import
6.description: One or more web resources were imported into an Application.

7.caption: Export
7.description: One or more web resources were exported from an Application.

8.caption: Share
8.description: One or more web resources were shared.

dst_endpoint.description: Details about server providing the web resources.

src_endpoint.description: Details about the endpoint from which the request originated.

base_event.caption: Base Event
base_event.description: The base event is a generic and concrete event. It also defines a set of attributes available in most event classes. As a generic event that does not belong to any event category, it could be used to log events that are not otherwise defined by the schema.
base_event.name: base_event

config_state.caption: Device Config State
config_state.description: Device Config State events report device configuration data.
config_state.name: config_state

device.description: The device that is being discovered by an inventory process.

discovery.caption: Discovery
discovery.description: The Discovery event is a generic event that defines a set of attributes available in Discovery category events. As a generic event, it could be used to log events that are not otherwise defined by the Discovery specific event classes.
discovery.name: discovery

1.caption: Log
1.description: The discovered information is via a log.

2.caption: Collect
2.description: The discovered information is via a collection process.

inventory_info.caption: Device Inventory Info
inventory_info.description: Device Inventory Info events report device inventory data.
inventory_info.name: inventory_info

device.description: The device that is being discovered by an inventory process.

findings.caption: Findings
findings.name: findings
findings.description: Findings events report findings, detections, and possible resolutions of malware, anomalies, or actions performed by security products.

1.caption: Create
1.description: A security finding is created.

2.caption: Update
2.description: A security finding is updated.

security_finding.caption: Security Finding
security_finding.description: Security Finding events describe findings, detections, anomalies, alerts and/or actions performed by security products
security_finding.name: security_finding

attacks.description: The attack object describes the technique and associated tactics as defined by ATT&CK MatrixTM.

state.description: The normalized state of a security finding.

state_id.description: The normalized state identifier of a security finding.

1.caption: New
1.description: The finding is new and yet to be reviewed.

2.caption: In Progress
2.description: The finding is under review.

3.caption: Suppressed
3.description: The finding was reviewed, considered as a false positive and is now suppressed.

4.caption: Resolved
4.description: The finding was reviewed and remediated and is now considered resolved.

account_change.caption: Account Change
account_change.description: Account Change events report when specific user account management tasks are performed, such as a user/role being created, changed, deleted, renamed, disabled, enabled, locked out or unlocked.
account_change.name: account_change

1.caption: Create
1.description: A user/role was created.

2.caption: Enable
2.description: A user/role was enabled.

3.caption: Password Change
3.description: An attempt was made to change an account's password.

4.caption: Password Reset
4.description: An attempt was made to reset an account's password.

9.caption: Lock
9.description: A user account was locked out.

http_request.description: Details about the underlying http request.

src_endpoint.description: Details about the source of the activity.

user.description: The user that was a target of an activity.

authentication.caption: Authentication
authentication.description: Authentication events report authentication session activities such as user attempts a logon or logoff, successfully or otherwise.
authentication.name: authentication

1.caption: Logon
1.description: A new logon session was requested.

2.caption: Logoff
2.description: A logon session was terminated and no longer exists.

3.caption: Authentication Ticket
3.description: A Kerberos authentication ticket (TGT) was requested.

4.caption: Service Ticket
4.description: A Kerberos service ticket was requested.

actor.description: The actor that requested the authentication.

certificate.description: The certificate associated with the authentication or pre-authentication (Kerberos).

dst_endpoint.description: The endpoint to which the authentication was targeted.

http_request.description: Details about the underlying http request.

is_remote.description: The attempted authentication is over a remote connection.

service.description: The service or gateway to which the user or process is being authenticated

src_endpoint.description: The Endpoint from which the authentication was requested.

status_detail.description:
The details about the authentication request. For example, possible details for Windows logon or logoff events are:
  • Success
    • LOGOFF_USER_INITIATED
    • LOGOFF_OTHER
  • Failure
    • USER_DOES_NOT_EXIST
    • INVALID_CREDENTIALS
    • ACCOUNT_DISABLED
    • ACCOUNT_LOCKED_OUT
    • PASSWORD_EXPIRED

user.description: The subject (user/role or account) to authenticate.

authorize_session.caption: Authorize Session
authorize_session.description: Authorize Session events report privileges or groups assigned to a new user session, usually at login time.
authorize_session.name: authorize_session

dst_endpoint.description: The Endpoint for which the user session was targeted.

group.description: Group that was assigned to the new user session.

privileges.description: The list of sensitive privileges, assigned to the new user session.

session.description: The user session with the assigned privileges.

user.description: The user to which new privileges were assigned.

entity_management.caption: Entity Management
entity_management.name: entity_management
entity_management.description: Entity Management events report activity by a managed client, a micro service, or a user at a management console. The activity can be a create, read, update, and delete operation on a managed entity.

actor.description: Use for when the entity acting upon another entity is a process or user.

comment.description: The user provided comment about why the entity was changed.

group_management.caption: Group Management
group_management.description: Group Management events report management updates to a group, including updates to membership and permissions.
group_management.name: group_management

1.description: Assign privileges to a group.
1.caption: Assign Privileges

2.description: Revoke privileges from a group.
2.caption: Revoke Privileges

3.description: Add user to a group.
3.caption: Add User

4.description: Remove user from a group.
4.caption: Remove User

group.description: Group that was the target of the event.

privileges.description: A list of privileges assigned to the group.

resource.description: Resource that the privileges give access to.

user.description: A user that was added to or removed from the group.

iam.caption: Identity & Access Management
iam.description: The Identity & Access Management event is a generic event that defines a set of attributes available in the access control events. As a generic event, it could be used to log events that are not otherwise defined by the IAM category.
iam.name: iam

user_access.caption: User Access Management
user_access.description: User Access Management events report management updates to a user's privileges.
user_access.name: user_access

1.description: Assign privileges to a user.
1.caption: Assign Privileges

2.description: Revoke privileges from a user.
2.caption: Revoke Privileges

privileges.description: List of privileges assigned to a user.

resource.description: Resource that the privileges give access to.

user.description: User to which privileges were assigned.

dhcp_activity.caption: DHCP Activity
dhcp_activity.description: DHCP Activity events report MAC to IP assignment via DHCP from a client or server.
dhcp_activity.name: dhcp_activity

1.caption: Discover
1.description: DHCPDISCOVER

2.caption: Offer
2.description: DHCPOFFER

3.caption: Request
3.description: DHCPREQUEST

4.caption: Decline
4.description: DHCPDECLINE

5.caption: Ack
5.description: DHCPACK: The server accepts the request by sending the client a DHCP Acknowledgment message.

7.caption: Release
7.description: DHCPRELEASE: A DHCP client sends a DHCPRELEASE packet to the server to release the IP address and cancel any remaining lease.

dst_endpoint.description: The responder (server) of the DHCP connection.

src_endpoint.description: The initiator (client) of the DHCP connection.

transaction_uid.description: The unique identifier of the transaction. This is typically a random number generated from the client to associate a dhcp request/response pair.

dns_activity.caption: DNS Activity
dns_activity.description: DNS Activity events report DNS queries and answers as seen on the network.
dns_activity.name: dns_activity

rcode.description: The DNS server response code, normalized to the caption of the rcode_id value. In the case of 'Other', it is defined by the event source.

rcode_id.caption: Response Code ID
rcode_id.description: The normalized identifier of the DNS server response code. See RFC-6895.

1.caption: FormError
1.description: Format Error.

2.caption: ServError
2.description: Server Failure.

3.caption: NXDomain
3.description: Non-Existent Domain.

4.caption: NotImp
4.description: Not Implemented.

6.caption: YXDomain
6.description: Name Exists when it should not.

7.caption: YXRRSet
7.description: RR Set Exists when it should not.

8.caption: NXRRSet
8.description: RR Set that should exist does not.

9.caption: NotAuth
9.description: Not Authorized or Server Not Authoritative for zone.

16.caption: BADSIG_VERS
16.description: TSIG Signature Failure or Bad OPT Version.

24.caption: Unassigned
24.description: The codes deemed to be unassigned by the RFC (unassigned codes: 12-15, 24-3840, 4096-65534).

25.caption: Reserved
25.description: The codes deemed to be reserved by the RFC (codes: 3841-4095, 65535).

99.caption: Other
99.description: The dns response code is not defined by the RFC.

email_activity.description: Email events report activities of emails.
email_activity.caption: Email Activity
email_activity.name: email_activity

3.caption: Scan
3.description: Email being scanned (example: security scanning)

attempt.description: The attempt number for attempting to deliver the email.

direction.description: The direction of the email, as defined by the direction_id value.

direction_id.description:
The direction of the email relative to the scanning host or organization.

Email scanned at an internet gateway might be characterized as inbound to the organization from the Internet, outbound from the organization to the Internet, or internal within the organization. Email scanned at a workstation might be characterized as inbound to, or outbound from the workstation.

1.caption: Inbound
1.description: Email Inbound, from the Internet or outside network destined for an entity inside network.

2.caption: Outbound
2.description: Email Outbound, from inside the network destined for an entity outside network.

3.caption: Internal
3.description: Email Internal, from inside the network destined for an entity inside network.

smtp_hello.description: The value of the SMTP HELO or EHLO command sent by the initiator (client).

email_file_activity.description: Email File Activity events report files within emails.
email_file_activity.caption: Email File Activity
email_file_activity.name: email_file_activity

3.caption: Scan
3.description: Email file being scanned (example: security scanning).

email_url_activity.description: Email URL Activity events report URLs within an email.
email_url_activity.caption: Email URL Activity
email_url_activity.name: email_url_activity

3.caption: Scan
3.description: Email URL being scanned (example: security scanning).

url.description: The URL included in the email content.

network_file_activity.caption: Network File Activity
network_file_activity.description: Network File Activity events report activities on a cloud file storage service such as Box, MS OneDrive, or Google Drive.
network_file_activity.name: network_file_activity

actor.description: The actor that performed the activity on the target file.

file.description: The file that is the target of the activity.

src_endpoint.description: The endpoint that performed the activity on the target file.

ftp_activity.caption: FTP Activity
ftp_activity.description: File Transfer Protocol (FTP) Activity events report file transfers between a server and a client as seen on the network.
ftp_activity.name: ftp_activity

1.caption: Put
1.description: File upload to the FTP or SFTP site.

2.caption: Get
2.description: File download from the FTP or SFTP site.

3.caption: Poll
3.description: Poll directory for specific file(s) or folder(s) at the FTP or SFTP site location.

4.caption: Delete
4.description: Delete file(s) from the FTP or SFTP site.

5.caption: Rename
5.description: Rename the file(s) in the FTP or SFTP site.

6.caption: List
6.description: List files in a specified directory.

codes.description: The list of return codes to the FTP command.

command_responses.description: The list of responses to the FTP command.

name.description: The name of the data affiliated with the command.

port.description: The dynamic port established for impending data transfers.

type.description: The type of FTP network connection (e.g. active, passive).

http_activity.caption: HTTP Activity
http_activity.name: http_activity
http_activity.description: HTTP Activity events report HTTP connection and traffic information.

network_activity.caption: Network Activity
network_activity.description: Network Activity events report network connection and traffic activity.
network_activity.name: network_activity

rdp_activity.caption: RDP Activity
rdp_activity.description: Remote Desktop Protocol (RDP) Activity events report remote client connections to a server as seen on the network.
rdp_activity.name: rdp_activity

1.caption: Initial Request
1.description: The initial RDP request.

2.caption: Initial Response
2.description: The initial RDP response.

3.caption: Connect Request
3.description: An RDP connection request.

4.caption: Connect Response
4.description: An RDP connection response.

certificate_chain.description: The list of observed certificates in an RDP TLS connection.

device.description: The device instigating the RDP connection.

request.description: The client request in an RDP network connection.

response.description: The server response in an RDP network connection.

smb_activity.caption: SMB Activity
smb_activity.description: Server Message Block (SMB) Protocol Activity events report client/server connections sharing resources within the network.
smb_activity.name: smb_activity

1.caption: File Supersede
1.description: The event pertains to file superseded activity (overwritten if it exists and created if not).

2.caption: File Open
2.description: The event pertains to file open activity (the file is opened if it exists and fails to open if it doesn't).

3.caption: File Create
3.description: The event pertains to file creation activity (a file is created if it does not exist and fails if it does).

4.caption: File Open If
4.description: The event pertains to file open activity (the file is opened if it exists and is created if it doesn't).

5.caption: File Overwrite
5.description: The event pertains to file overwrite activity (the file is opened in a truncated form if it exists and fails if it doesn't).

6.caption: File Overwrite If
6.description: The event pertains to file overwrite activity (the file is opened in a truncated form if it exists and created otherwise)

file.description: The file that is the target of the SMB activity.

open_type.description: Indicates how the file was opened (e.g. normal, delete on close).

response.description: The server response in an SMB network connection.

ssh_activity.caption: SSH Activity
ssh_activity.description: SSH Activity events report remote client connections to a server using the Secure Shell (SSH) Protocol.
ssh_activity.name: ssh_activity

file_activity.caption: File System Activity
file_activity.description: File System Activity events report when a process performs an action on a file or folder.
file_activity.name: file_activity

activity_id.description: The activity ID of the event.

actor.description: The actor that performed the activity on the file object

file.description: The file that is the target of the activity.

file_result.description: The resulting file object when the activity was allowed and successful.

kernel_activity.caption: Kernel Activity
kernel_activity.description: Kernel Activity events report when an process creates, reads, or deletes a kernel resource.
kernel_activity.name: kernel_activity

kernel_extension.caption: Kernel Extension Activity
kernel_extension.name: kernel_extension
kernel_extension.description: Kernel Extension events report when a driver/extension is loaded or unloaded into the kernel

actor.description: The actor process that loaded or unloaded the driver/extension.

memory_activity.caption: Memory Activity
memory_activity.description: Memory Activity events report when a process has memory allocated, read/modified, or other manipulation activities - such as a buffer overflow or turning off data execution protection (DEP).
memory_activity.name: memory_activity

base_address.description: The memory address that was access or requested.

size.description: The memory size that was access or requested.

process.description: The process that had memory allocated, read/written, or had other manipulation activities performed on it.

module_activity.caption: Module Activity
module_activity.description: Module Activity events report when a process loads or unloads the module.
module_activity.name: module_activity

actor.description: The actor that loaded or unloaded the module.

module.description: The module that was loaded or unloaded.

process_activity.name: process_activity
process_activity.caption: Process Activity
process_activity.description: Process Activity events report when a process launches, injects, opens or terminates another process, successful or otherwise.

actor.description: The actor that performed the activity on the target process. For example, the process that started a new process or injected code into another process.

module.description: The module that was injected by the actor process.

process.description: The process that was launched, injected into, opened, or terminated.

scheduled_job_activity.caption: Scheduled Job Activity
scheduled_job_activity.description: Scheduled Job Activity events report activities related to scheduled jobs or tasks.
scheduled_job_activity.name: scheduled_job_activity

actor.description: The actor that performed the activity on the job object.

system.caption: System Activity
system.description: The System Activity event is a generic event that defines a set of attributes available in the system activity events. As a generic event, it could be used to log events that are not otherwise defined by the System Activity category.
system.name: system

_dns.caption: DNS
_dns.name: _dns
_dns.description: The Domain Name System (DNS) object represents the shared information associated with the DNS query and answer objects.

class.description: The class of resource records being queried. See RFC1035. For example: IN.
class.caption: Resource Record Class

packet_uid.description: The DNS packet identifier assigned by the program that generated the query. The identifier is copied to the response.

type.description: The type of resource records being queried. See RFC1035. For example: A, AAAA, CNAME, MX, and NS.
type.caption: Resource Record Type

_entity.caption: Entity
_entity.name: _entity
_entity.description: The Entity object is an unordered collection of attributes, with a name and unique identifier. It serves as a base object that defines a set of attributes and default constraints available in all objects that extend it.

name.description: The name of the entity.

uid.description: The unique identifier of the entity.

_resource.caption: Resource
_resource.description: The Resource object contains attributes that provide information about a particular resource. It serves as a base object, offering attributes that help identify and classify the resource effectively.
_resource.name: _resource

labels.description: The list of labels/tags associated to a resource.

name.description: The name of the resource.

type.description: The resource type as defined by the event source.

uid.description: The unique identifier of the resource.

account.caption: Account
account.description: The Account object contains details about the account that initiated or performed a specific activity within a system or application.
account.name: account

name.description: The name of the account (e.g. GCP Account Name).

type.caption: Type
type.description: The account type, normalized to the caption of 'account_type_id'. In the case of 'Other', it is defined by the event source.

99.caption: Other
99.description: The account type is not mapped.

uid.description: The unique identifier of the account (e.g. AWS Account ID).

actor.caption: Actor
actor.description: The Actor object contains details about the user, role, or process that initiated or performed a specific activity.
actor.name: actor

process.description: The process that initiated the activity.

session.description: The user session from which the activity was initiated.

user.description: The user that initiated the activity or the user context from which the activity was initiated.

analytic.caption: Analytic
analytic.name: analytic
analytic.description: The Analytic object contains details about the analytic technique used to analyze and derive insights from the data or information that led to the finding or conclusion.

desc.description: The description of the analytic that generated the finding.

name.description: The name of the analytic that generated the finding.

related_analytics.description:: Other analytics related to this analytic

type.description: The analytic type.

uid.description: The unique identifier of the analytic that generated the finding.

api.caption: API
api.description: The API, or Application Programming Interface, object represents  information pertaining to an API request and response.
api.name: api

request.description: Details pertaining to the API request.

response.description: Details pertaining to the API response.

service.description: The information pertaining to the API service.

version.description: The version of the API service.

attack.caption: Attack
attack.name: attack
attack.description: The Attack object describes the technique and associated tactics related to an attack. See MITRE ATT&CK®.

authorization.caption: Authorization Result
authorization.description: The Authorization Result object provides details about the authorization outcome and associated policies related to activity.
authorization.name: authorization

policy.description: Details about the Identity/Access management policies that are applicable.

certificate.caption: Digital Certificate
certificate.name: certificate
certificate.description: The Digital Certificate, also known as a Public Key Certificate, object contains information about the ownership and usage of a public key. It serves as a means to establish trust in the authenticity and integrity of the public key and the associated entity. Defined by D3FEND d3f:Certificate.

created_time.description: The time when the certificate was created.

expiration_time.description: The expiration time of the certificate.

fingerprints.description: The fingerprint list of the certificate.

serial_number.description: The serial number of the certificate used to create the digital signature.
serial_number.caption: Certificate Serial Number

cis_benchmark_result.caption: CIS Benchmark Result
cis_benchmark_result.description: The CIS Benchmark Result object contains information as defined by the Center for Internet Security (CIS) benchmark result. CIS Benchmarks are a collection of best practices for securely configuring IT systems, software, networks, and cloud infrastructure.
cis_benchmark_result.name: cis_benchmark_result

name.description: The CIS benchmark name.

cis_control.caption: CIS Control
cis_control.description: The CIS Control contains information as defined by the Center for Internet Security Critical Security Control (CIS CSC). Prioritized set of actions to protect your organization and data from cyber-attack vectors.
cis_control.name: cis_control

version.description: The CIS critical security control version.

cloud.caption: Cloud
cloud.description: The Cloud object contains information about a cloud account such as AWS Account ID, regions, etc.
cloud.name: cloud

provider.description: The unique name of the Cloud services provider, such as AWS, MS Azure, GCP, etc.

region.description: The name of the cloud region, as defined by the cloud provider.

zone.description: The availability zone in the cloud region, as defined by the cloud provider.

compliance.caption: Compliance
compliance.description: The Compliance object contains information about compliance requirements related of a finding generated by security tool.
compliance.name: compliance

container.caption: Container
container.name: container
container.description: The Container object describes an instance of a specific container. A container is a prepackaged, portable system image that runs isolated on an existing system using a container runtime like containerd.

name.description: The container name.

image.description: The container image used as a template to run the container.

uid.description: The full container unique identifier for this instantiation of the container. For example: ac2ea168264a08f9aaca0dfc82ff3551418dfd22d02b713142a6843caa2f61bf.

tag.description: The tag used by the container. It can indicate version, format, OS.

size.description: The size of the container image.

hash.description: Commit hash of image created for docker or the SHA256 hash of the container. For example: 13550340a8681c84c861aac2e5b440161c2b33a3e4f302ac680ca5b686de48de.

cve.caption: CVE
cve.description: The Common Vulnerabilities and Exposures (CVE) object represents publicly disclosed cybersecurity vulnerabilities defined in CVE Program catalog (CVE). There is one CVE Record for each vulnerability in the catalog.
cve.name: cve

modified_time.caption: Record Modified Date
modified_time.description: The Record Modified Date identifies when the CVE record was last updated.

created_time.caption: Record Creation Date
created_time.description: The Record Creation Date identifies when the CVE ID was issued to a CVE Numbering Authority (CNA) or the CVE Record was published on the CVE List. Note that the Record Creation Date does not necessarily indicate when this vulnerability was discovered, shared with the affected vendor, publicly disclosed, or updated in CVE.

uid.caption: CVE ID
uid.description: The Common Vulnerabilities and Exposures unique number assigned to a specific computer vulnerability. A CVE Identifier begins with 4 digits representing the year followed by a sequence of digits that acts as a unique identifier. For example: CVE-2021-12345.

product.description: The product where the vulnerability was discovered.

type.caption: Vulnerability Type
type.description:
The vulnerability type as selected from a large dropdown menu during CVE refinement.

Most frequently used vulnerability types are: DoS, Code Execution, Overflow, Memory Corruption, Sql Injection, XSS, Directory Traversal, Http Response Splitting, Bypass something, Gain Information, Gain Privileges, CSRF, File Inclusion. For more information see Vulnerabilities By Type distributions.

cvss.caption: CVSS Score
cvss.description: The Common Vulnerability Scoring System (CVSS) object provides a way to capture the principal characteristics of a vulnerability and produce a numerical score reflecting its severity.
cvss.name: cvss

base_score.description: The CVSS base score. For example: 9.1.

metrics.description: The Common Vulnerability Scoring System metrics.This attribute contains information on the CVE's impact. If the CVE has been analyzed, this attribute will contain any CVSSv2 or CVSSv3 information associated with the vulnerability. For example: {{"Access Vector", "Network"}, {"Access Complexity", "Low"}, ...}.

overall_score.description: The CVSS overall score, impacted by base, temporal, and environmental metrics. For example: 9.1.

severity.description:
The Common Vulnerability Scoring System (CVSS) Qualitative Severity Rating. A textual representation of the numeric score.

CVSS v2.0
  • Low (0.0 – 3.9)
  • Medium (4.0 – 6.9)
  • High (7.0 – 10.0)

CVSS v3.0
  • None (0.0)
  • Low (0.1 - 3.9)
  • Medium (4.0 - 6.9)
  • High (7.0 - 8.9)
  • Critical (9.0 - 10.0)

dce_rpc.caption: DCE/RPC
dce_rpc.name: dce_rpc
dce_rpc.description: The DCE/RPC, or Distributed Computing Environment/Remote Procedure Call, object describes the remote procedure call system for distributed computing environments. Defined by D3FEND d3f:RemoteProcedureCall.

command_response.description: The reply to the request command (e.g. RESPONSE, BINDACK or FAULT).

device.caption: Device
device.description: The Device object represents an addressable computer system or host, which is typically connected to a computer network and participates in the transmission or processing of data within the computer network. Defined by D3FEND d3f:Host.
device.name: device

created_time.description: The time when the device was known to have been created.

desc.caption: Description
desc.description: The description of the device, ordinarily as reported by the operating system.

domain.description: The network domain where the device resides. For example: work.example.com.

first_seen_time.description: The initial discovery time of the device.

groups.description: The group names to which the device belongs. For example: <code>["Windows Laptops", "Engineering"]<code/>.

image.description: The image used as a template to run the virtual machine.

ip.description: The device IP address, in either IPv4 or IPv6 format.

last_seen_time.description: The most recent discovery time of the device.

location.description: The geographical location of the device.

mac.description: The device Media Access Control (MAC) address.

modified_time.description: The time when the device was last known to have been modified.

name.description:
The alternate device name, ordinarily as assigned by an administrator.

Note: The Name could be any other string that helps to identify the device, such as a phone number; for example 310-555-1234.

org.description: Organization and org unit related to the device.

region.description: The region where the virtual machine is located. For example, an AWS Region.

type.caption: Type
type.description: The device type. For example: unknown, server, desktop, laptop, tablet, mobile, virtual, browser, or other.

uid.description: The unique identifier of the device. For example the Windows TargetSID or AWS EC2 ARN.

uid_alt.description: An alternate unique identifier of the device if any. For example the ActiveDirectory DN.

device_hw_info.caption: Device Hardware Info
device_hw_info.name: device_hw_info
device_hw_info.description: The Device Hardware Information object contains details and specifications of the physical components that make up a device. This information provides an overview of the hardware capabilities, configuration, and characteristics of the device.

digital_signature.caption: Digital Signature
digital_signature.name: digital_signature
digital_signature.description: The Digital Signature object contains information about the cryptographic mechanism used to verify the authenticity, integrity, and origin of the file or application.

algorithm.description: The digital signature algorithm used to create the signature, normalized to the caption of 'algorithm_id'. In the case of 'Other', it is defined by the event source.

algorithm_id.description: The identifier of the normalized digital signature algorithm.

1.caption: DSA
1.description: Digital Signature Algorithm (DSA).

2.caption: RSA
2.description: Rivest-Shamir-Adleman (RSA) Algorithm.

3.caption: ECDSA
3.description: Elliptic Curve Digital Signature Algorithm.

4.caption: Authenticode
4.description: Microsoft Authenticode Digital Signature Algorithm.

created_time.description: The time when the digital signature was created.

display.caption: Display
display.name: display
display.description: The Display object contains information about the physical or virtual display connected to a computer system.

dns_answer.caption: DNS Answer
dns_answer.description: The DNS Answer object represents a specific response provided by the Domain Name System (DNS) when querying for information about a domain or performing a DNS operation. It encapsulates the relevant details and data returned by the DNS server in response to a query.
dns_answer.name: dns_answer

class.description: The class of DNS data contained in this resource record. See RFC1035. For example: IN.

flag_ids.caption: DNS Header Flags
flag_ids.description: The list of DNS answer header flag IDs.

99.caption: Other
99.description: The event DNS header flag is not mapped.

flags.caption: DNS Header Flags
flags.description: The list of DNS answer header flags.

type.description: The type of data contained in this resource record. See RFC1035. For example: CNAME.

dns_query.caption: DNS Query
dns_query.name: dns_query
dns_query.description: The DNS query object represents a specific request made to the Domain Name System (DNS) to retrieve information about a domain or perform a DNS operation. This object encapsulates the necessary attributes and methods to construct and send DNS queries, specify the query type (e.g., A, AAAA, MX). Defined by D3FEND d3f:DNSLookup.

hostname.description: The hostname or domain being queried. For example: www.example.com

email.caption: Email
email.description: The Email object describes the email metadata such as sender, recipients, and direction. Defined by D3FEND d3f:Email.
email.name: email

size.description: The size in bytes of the email, including attachments.

subject.caption: Subject
subject.description: The email header Subject value, as defined by RFC 5322.

uid.caption: Email UID
uid.description: The email unique identifier.

email_auth.caption: Email Authentication
email_auth.name: email_auth
email_auth.description: The Email Authentication object describes the Sender Policy Framework (SPF), DomainKeys Identified Mail (DKIM) and Domain-based Message Authentication, Reporting and Conformance (DMARC) attributes of an email.

endpoint.caption: Endpoint
endpoint.description: The Endpoint object describes a physical or virtual device that connects to and exchanges information with a computer network. Some examples of endpoints are mobile devices, desktop computers, virtual machines, embedded devices, and servers. Internet-of-Things devices—like cameras, lighting, refrigerators, security systems, smart speakers, and thermostats—are also endpoints.
endpoint.name: endpoint

hostname.description: The fully qualified name of the endpoint.

ip.description: The IP address of the endpoint, in either IPv4 or IPv6 format.

location.description: The geographical location of the endpoint.

mac.description: The Media Access Control (MAC) address of the endpoint.

name.description: The short name of the endpoint.

uid.description: The unique identifier of the endpoint.

enrichment.caption: Enrichment
enrichment.description: The Enrichment object provides inline enrichment data for specific attributes of interest within an event. It serves as a mechanism to enhance or supplement the information associated with the event by adding additional relevant details or context.
enrichment.name: enrichment

data.description: The enrichment data associated with the attribute and value. The meaning of this data depends on the type the enrichment record.

name.description: The name of the attribute to which the enriched data pertains.

type.description: The enrichment type. For example: location.

value.description: The value of the attribute to which the enriched data pertains.

extension.caption: Schema Extension
extension.name: extension
extension.description: The OCSF Schema Extension object provides detailed information about the schema extension used to construct the event. The schema extensions are registered in the extensions.md file.

name.description: The schema extension name. For example: dev.

uid.description: The schema extension unique identifier. For example: 999.

version.description: The schema extension version. For example: 1.0.0-alpha.2.

feature.caption: Feature
feature.name: feature
feature.description: The Feature object provides information about the software product feature that generated a specific event. It encompasses details related to the capabilities, components, user interface (UI) design, and performance upgrades associated with the feature.

name.description: The name of the feature.

uid.description: The unique identifier of the feature.

file.caption: File
file.name: file
file.description: The File object represents the metadata associated with a file stored in a computer system. It encompasses information about the file itself, including its attributes, properties, and organizational details. Defined by D3FEND d3f:File.

created_time.description: The time when the file was created.

creator.description: The user that created the file.

desc.description: The description of the file, as returned by file system. For example: the description as returned by the Unix file command or the Windows file type.

modified_time.description: The time when the file was last modified.

modifier.description: The user that last modified the file.

name.description: The name of the file. For example: svchost.exe

path.description: The full path to the file. For example: c:\windows\system32\svchost.exe.

product.description: The product that created or installed the file.

type.description: The file type.

uid.description: The unique identifier of the file as defined by the storage system, such the file system file ID.

finding.caption: Finding
finding.description: The Finding object contains details related to a security finding generated by a security tool or system. It encompasses information about potential security vulnerabilities, weaknesses, misconfigurations, or suspicious activities identified during security assessments or monitoring processes.
finding.name: finding

created_time.description: The time when the finding was created.

desc.description: The description of the reported finding.

first_seen_time.description: The time when the finding was first observed.

last_seen_time.description: The time when the finding was most recently observed.

modified_time.description: The time when the finding was last modified.

product_uid.description: The unique identifier of the product that reported the finding.

src_url.description: The URL pointing to the source of the finding.

title.description: The title of the reported finding.

types.description: One or more types of the reported finding.

uid.description: The unique identifier of the reported finding.

fingerprint.caption: Fingerprint
fingerprint.description: The Fingerprint object provides detailed information about a digital fingerprint, which is a compact representation of data used to identify a longer piece of information, such as a public key or file content. It contains the algorithm and value of the fingerprint, enabling efficient and reliable identification of the associated data.
fingerprint.name: fingerprint

algorithm.description: The hash algorithm used to create the digital fingerprint, normalized to the caption of 'algorithm_id'. In the case of 'Other', it is defined by the event source.

algorithm_id.description: The identifier of the normalized hash algorithm, which was used to create the digital fingerprint.

1.caption: MD5
1.description: MD5 message-digest algorithm producing a 128-bit (16-byte) hash value.

2.caption: SHA-1
2.description: Secure Hash Algorithm 1 producing a 160-bit (20-byte) hash value.

3.caption: SHA-256
3.description: Secure Hash Algorithm 2 producing a 256-bit (32-byte) hash value.

4.caption: SHA-512
4.description: Secure Hash Algorithm 2 producing a 512-bit (64-byte) hash value.

5.caption: CTPH
5.description: The ssdeep generated fuzzy checksum. Also known as Context Triggered Piecewise Hash (CTPH).

7.caption: quickXorHash
7.description: Microsoft simple non-cryptographic hash algorithm that works by XORing the bytes in a circular-shifting fashion.

group.caption: Group
group.description: The Group object represents a collection or association of entities, such as users, policies, or devices. It serves as a logical grouping mechanism to organize and manage entities with similar characteristics or permissions within a system or organization.
group.name: group

name.description: The group name.

type.description: The type of the group or account.
type.caption: Account Type

uid.description: The unique identifier of the group. For example, for Windows events this is the security identifier (SID) of the group.

hassh.caption: HASSH
hassh.description: The HASSH (Honeypot Attention-Grabbing SSH) object contains SSH network fingerprinting values for specific client/server implementations. It provides a standardized way of identifying and categorizing SSH connections based on their unique characteristics and behavior.
hassh.name: hassh

algorithm.description: The concatenation of key exchange, encryption, authentication and compression algorithms (separated by ';'). NOTE: This is not the underlying algorithm for the hash implementation.

fingerprint.description: The hash of the key exchange, encryption, authentication and compression algorithms.

http_cookie.caption: HTTP Cookie
http_cookie.description: The HTTP Cookie object, also known as a web cookie or browser cookie, contains details and values pertaining to a small piece of data that a server sends to a user's web browser. This data is then stored by the browser and sent back to the server with subsequent requests, allowing the server to remember and track certain information about the user's browsing session or preferences.
http_cookie.name: http_cookie

expiration_time.description: The expiration time of the HTTP cookie.

name.description: The HTTP cookie name.

path.description: The path of the HTTP cookie.

http_header.caption: HTTP Header
http_header.description: TThe HTTP Header object represents the headers sent in an HTTP request or response. HTTP headers are key-value pairs that convey additional information about the HTTP message, including details about the content, caching, authentication, encoding, and other aspects of the communication.
http_header.name: http_header

name.description: The name of the header

http_request.caption: HTTP Request
http_request.description: The HTTP Request object represents the attributes of a request made to a web server. It encapsulates the details and metadata associated with an HTTP request, including the request method, headers, URL, query parameters, body content, and other relevant information.
http_request.name: http_request

http_method.caption: HTTP Method
http_method.description: The HTTP request method indicates the desired action to be performed for a given resource.

CONNECT.caption: Connect
CONNECT.description: The CONNECT method establishes a tunnel to the server identified by the target resource.

DELETE.caption: Delete
DELETE.description: The DELETE method deletes the specified resource.

GET.caption: Get
GET.description: The GET method requests a representation of the specified resource. Requests using GET should only retrieve data.

HEAD.caption: Head
HEAD.description: The HEAD method asks for a response identical to a GET request, but without the response body.

OPTIONS.caption: Options
OPTIONS.description: The OPTIONS method describes the communication options for the target resource.

POST.caption: Post
POST.description: The POST method submits an entity to the specified resource, often causing a change in state or side effects on the server.

PUT.caption: Put
PUT.description: The PUT method replaces all current representations of the target resource with the request payload.

TRACE.caption: Trace
TRACE.description: The TRACE method performs a message loop-back test along the path to the target resource.

uid.description: The unique identifier of the http request.

url.description: The URL object that pertains to the request.

http_response.caption: HTTP Response
http_response.description: The HTTP Response object contains detailed information about the response sent from a web server to the requester. It encompasses attributes and metadata that describe the response status, headers, body content, and other relevant information.
http_response.name: http_response

code.description: The numeric code sent from the web server to the requester.

status.description: The response status. For example: Kubernetes responseStatus.status.

idp.caption: Identity Provider
idp.description: The Identity Provider object contains detailed information about a provider responsible for creating, maintaining, and managing identity information while offering authentication services to applications. An Identity Provider (IdP) serves as a trusted authority that verifies the identity of users and issues authentication tokens or assertions to enable secure access to applications or services.
idp.name: idp

name.description: The name of the identity provider.

uid.description: The unique identifier of the identity provider.

image.caption: Image
image.name: image
image.description: The Image object provides a description of a specific Virtual Machine (VM) or Container image. Defined by D3FEND d3f:ContainerImage.

name.description: The image name. For example: elixir.

path.description: The full path to the image file.

uid.description: The unique image ID. For example: 77af4d6b9913.

job.caption: Job
job.name: job
job.description: The Job object provides information about a scheduled job or task, including its name, command line, and state. It encompasses attributes that describe the properties and status of the scheduled job.

created_time.description: The time when the job was created.

file.description: The file that pertains to the job.

last_run_time.description: The time when the job was last run.

name.description: The name of the job.

next_run_time.description: The time when the job will next be run.

run_state.description: The run state of the job.

run_state_id.description: The run state ID of the job.

user.description: The user that created the job.

kernel.caption: Kernel Resource
kernel.description: The Kernel Resource object provides information about a specific kernel resource, including its name and type. It describes essential attributes associated with a resource managed by the kernel of an operating system. Defined by D3FEND d3f:Kernel.
kernel.name: kernel

name.description: The name of the kernel resource.

path.description: The full path of the kernel resource.

type.description: The type of the kernel resource.

type_id.description: The type of the kernel resource.

kernel_driver.caption: Kernel Extension
kernel_driver.name: kernel_driver
kernel_driver.description: The Kernel Extension object describes a kernel driver that has been loaded or unloaded into the operating system (OS) kernel. Defined by D3FEND d3f:KernelModule.

keyboard_info.caption: Keyboard Information
keyboard_info.description: The Keyboard Information object contains details and attributes related to a computer or device keyboard. It encompasses information that describes the characteristics, capabilities, and configuration of the keyboard.
keyboard_info.name: keyboard_info

kill_chain.caption: Kill Chain
kill_chain.description: The Kill Chain object represents a single phase of a cyber attack, including the initial reconnaissance and planning stages up to the final objective of the attacker. It provides a detailed description of each phase and its associated activities within the broader context of a cyber attack. See Cyber Kill Chain®.
kill_chain.name: kill_chain

location.caption: Geo Location
location.description: The Geo Location object describes a geographical location, usually associated with an IP address. Defined by D3FEND d3f:PhysicalLocation.
location.name: location

desc.description: The description of the geographical location.

provider.description: The provider of the geographical location data.

region.description: The alphanumeric code that identifies the principal subdivision (e.g. province or state) of the country. Region codes are defined at ISO 3166-2 and have a limit of three characters. For example, see the region codes for the US.

malware.caption: Malware
malware.description: The Malware object describes the classification of known malicious software, which is intentionally designed to cause damage to a computer, server, client, or computer network.
malware.name: malware

name.description: The malware name, as reported by the detection engine.

path.description: The filesystem path of the malware that was observed.

provider.description: The provider of the malware information.

uid.description: The malware unique identifier, as reported by the detection engine. For example a virus id or an IPS signature id.

managed_entity.caption: Managed Entity
managed_entity.description: The Managed Entity object describes the type and version of an entity, such as a policy or configuration.
managed_entity.name: managed_entity

data.description: The managed entity content as a JSON object.

name.description: The name of the managed entity.

type.description: The managed entity type. For example: policy, user, organizational unit, device.

uid.description: The identifier of the managed entity.

version.description: The version of the managed entity. For example: 1.2.3.

metadata.caption: Metadata
metadata.description: The Metadata object describes the metadata associated with the event. Defined by D3FEND d3f:Metadata.
metadata.name: metadata

labels.description:
The list of category labels attached to the event or specific attributes. Labels are user defined tags or aliases added at normalization time.

For example: ["network", "connection.ip:destination", "device.ip:source"]

modified_time.description: The time when the event was last modified or enriched.

uid.caption: Event UID
uid.description: The logging system-assigned unique identifier of an event instance.

version.description: The version of the OCSF schema, using Semantic Versioning Specification (SemVer). For example: 1.0.0. Event consumers use the version to determine the available event attributes.

metric.caption: Metric
metric.description: The Metric object defines a simple name/value pair entity for a metric.
metric.name: metric

name.description: The name of the metric.

module.caption: Module
module.description: The Module object describes the load attributes of a module.
module.name: module

1.caption: Standard
1.description: A normal module loaded by the normal windows loading mechanism i.e. LoadLibrary.

2.caption: Non Standard
2.description: A module loaded in a way avoidant of normal windows procedures. i.e. Bootstrapped Loading/Manual Dll Loading.

3.caption: ShellCode
3.description: A raw module in process memory that is READWRITE_EXECUTE and had a thread started in its range.

4.caption: Mapped
4.description: A memory mapped file, typically created with CreatefileMapping/MapViewOfFile.

5.caption: NonStandard Backed
5.description: A module loaded in a non standard way. However, GetModuleFileName succeeds on this allocation.

type.description: The module type.

network_connection_info.caption: Network Connection Information
network_connection_info.description: The Network Connection Information object describes characteristics of a network connection. Defined by D3FEND d3f:NetworkSession.
network_connection_info.name: network_connection_info

uid.caption: Connection UID
uid.description: The unique identifier of the connection.

network_endpoint.caption: Network Endpoint
network_endpoint.description: The Network Endpoint object describes characteristics of a network endpoint. These can be a source or destination of a network connection.
network_endpoint.name: network_endpoint

port.description: The port used for communication within the network connection.

network_interface.caption: Network Interface
network_interface.description: The Network Interface object describes the type and associated attributes of a network interface.
network_interface.name: network_interface

hostname.description: The hostname associated with the network interface.

ip.description: The IP address associated with the network interface.

mac.description: The MAC address of the network interface.

name.description: The name of the network interface.

type.description: The type of network interface.

uid.description: The unique identifier for the network interface.

network_proxy.caption: Network Proxy Endpoint
network_proxy.description: The Network Proxy Endpoint describes characteristics of a network proxy. Defined by D3FEND d3f:ProxyServer.
network_proxy.name: network_proxy

network_traffic.caption: Network Traffic
network_traffic.description: The Network Traffic object describes characteristics of network traffic. Network traffic refers to data moving across a network at a given point of time. Defined by D3FEND d3f:NetworkTraffic.
network_traffic.name: network_traffic

object.description: An unordered collection of attributes. It defines a set of attributes available in all objects. It can be also used as a generic object to log objects that are not otherwise defined by the schema.
object.caption: Object
object.name: object

observable.caption: Observable
observable.name: observable
observable.description: The observable object is a pivot element that contains related information found in many places in the event.

name.description: The full name of the observable attribute. The name is a pointer/reference to an attribute within the event data. For example: file.name.

type.description: The observable value type name.

99.caption: Other
99.description: The observable data type is not mapped. See the type attribute, which may contain data source specific value.

value.description:
The value associated with the observable attribute. The meaning of the value depends on the observable type.
If the name refers to a scalar attribute, then the value is the value of the attribute.
If the name refers to an object attribute, then the value is not populated.

organization.caption: Organization
organization.description: The Organization object describes characteristics of an organization or company and its division if any.
organization.name: organization

name.description: The name of the organization. For example, Widget, Inc.

uid.description: The unique identifier of the organization. For example, its Active Directory or AWS Org ID.

os.caption: Operating System (OS)
os.description: The Operating System (OS) object describes characteristics of an OS, such as Linux or Windows. Defined by D3FEND d3f:OperatingSystem.
os.name: os

country.description: The operating system country code, as defined by the ISO 3166-1 standard (Alpha-2 code). For the complete list of country codes, see ISO 3166-1 alpha-2 codes.

name.description: The operating system name.

type.description: The type of the operating system.

type_id.description: The type identifier of the operating system.

version.description: The version of the OS running on the device that originated the event. For example: "Windows 10", "OS X 10.7", or "iOS 9".

package.caption: Software Package
package.description: The Software Package object describes details about a software package. Defined by D3FEND d3f:SoftwarePackage.
package.name: package

license.description: The software license applied to this package.

name.description: The software package name.

policy.caption: Policy
policy.description:
The Policy object describes the policies that are applicable.

Policy attributes provide traceability to the operational state of the security product at the time that the event was captured, facilitating forensics, troubleshooting, and policy tuning/adjustments.
policy.name: policy

name.description: The policy name. For example: IAM Policy.

uid.description: A unique identifier of the policy instance.

process.caption: Process
process.description: The Process object describes a running instance of a launched program. Defined by D3FEND d3f:Process.
process.name: process

created_time.description: The time when the process was created/started.

name.description: The friendly name of the process, for example: Notepad++.

session.description: The user session under which this process is running.

terminated_time.description: The time when the process was terminated.

uid.description: A unique identifier for this process assigned by the producer (tool).  Facilitates correlation of a process event with other events for that process.

user.description: The user under which this process is running.

xattributes.description: An unordered collection of zero or more name/value pairs that represent a process extended attribute.

product.caption: Product
product.description: The Product object describes characteristics of a software product.
product.name: product

name.description: The name of the product.

path.description: The installation path of the product.

uid.description: The unique identifier of the product.

url_string.description: The URL pointing towards the product.

vendor_name.description: The name of the vendor of the product.

version.description: The version of the product, as defined by the event source. For example: 2013.1.3-beta.

related_event.caption: Related Event
related_event.description: The Related Event object describes an event related to a finding or detection as identified by the security product.
related_event.name: related_event

product_uid.description: The unique identifier of the product that reported the related event.

type.description: The type of the related event. For example: Process Activity: Launch.

type_uid.description: The unique identifier of the related event type. For example: 100701.

uid.description: The unique identifier of the related event.

remediation.caption: Remediation
remediation.description: The Remediation object describes details about recommended remediation strategies.
remediation.name: remediation

desc.description: The description of the remediation strategy.

reputation.caption: Reputation
reputation.description: The Reputation object describes the reputation/risk score of an entity (e.g. device, user, domain).
reputation.name: reputation

base_score.caption: Reputation Score
base_score.description: The reputation score as reported by the event source.

provider.description: The provider of the reputation information.

request.caption: Request Elements
request.description: The Request Elements object describes characteristics of an API request.
request.name: request

uid.description: The unique request identifier.

resource_details.caption: Resource Details
resource_details.description: The Resource Details object describes details about resources that were affected by the activity/event.
resource_details.name: resource_details

criticality.description: The criticality of the resource as defined by the event source.

group.description: The name of the related resource group.

owner.description: The identity of the service or user account that owns the resource.

region.description: The cloud region of the resource.

version.description: The version of the resource. For example 1.2.3.

response.caption: Response Elements
response.description: The Response Elements object describes characteristics of an API response.
response.name: response

rpc_interface.caption: RPC Interface
rpc_interface.name: rpc_interface
rpc_interface.description: The RPC Interface represents the remote procedure call interface used in the DCE/RPC session.

uuid.description: The unique identifier of the particular remote procedure or service.

version.description: The version of the DCE/RPC protocol being used in the session.

rule.caption: Rule
rule.description: The Rule object describes characteristics of a rule associated with a policy or an event.
rule.name: rule

desc.description: The description of the rule that generated the event.

name.description: The name of the rule that generated the event.

type.description: The rule type.

uid.description: The unique identifier of the rule that generated the event.

san.caption: Subject Alternative Name
san.description: The Subject Alternative name (SAN) object describes a SAN secured by a digital certificate
san.name: san

name.description: Name of SAN (e.g. The actual IP Address or domain.)

type.description: Type descriptor of SAN (e.g. IP Address/domain/etc.)

service.caption: Service
service.description: The Service object describes characteristics of a service, e.g. AWS EC2.
service.name: service

labels.description: The list of labels associated with the service.

name.description: The name of the service.

uid.description: The unique identifier of the service.

session.caption: Session
session.description: The Session object describes details about an authenticated session. e.g. Session Creation Time, Session Issuer. Defined by D3FEND d3f:Session.
session.name: session

created_time.description: The time when the session was created.

issuer.description: The identifier of the session issuer.

uid.description: The unique identifier of the session.

uuid.description: The universally unique identifier of the session.

tactic.caption: Tactic
tactic.description: The Tactic object describes the tactic IDs and/or name that are associated with the attack technique, as defined by ATT&CK MatrixTM.
tactic.name: tactic

name.description: The tactic name that is associated with the attack technique, as defined by ATT&CK MatrixTM.

uid.description: The tactic ID that is associated with the attack technique, as defined by ATT&CK MatrixTM.

technique.caption: Technique
technique.description: The Technique object describes the technique related to an attack, as defined by ATT&CK MatrixTM.
technique.name: technique

name.description: The name of the attack technique, as defined by ATT&CK MatrixTM. For example: Drive-by Compromise.

uid.description: The unique identifier of the attack technique, as defined by ATT&CK MatrixTM. For example: T1189.

tls.caption: Transport Layer Security (TLS)
tls.description: The Transport Layer Security (TLS) object describes the negotiated TLS protocol used for secure communications over an establish network connection.
tls.name: tls

tls_extension.caption: TLS Extension
tls_extension.description: The TLS Extension object describes additional attributes that extend the base Transport Layer Security (TLS) object.
tls_extension.name: tls_extension

data.description: The data contains information specific to the particular extension type.

type.description: The TLS extension type. For example: Server Name.

type_id.description: The TLS extension type identifier. See The Transport Layer Security (TLS) extension page.

1.description: The Maximum Fragment Length Negotiation extension.
1.caption: maximum_fragment_length

14.description: The Use SRTP data protection extension.
14.caption: use_srtp

45.description: The Pre-Shared Key Exchange Modes extension.
45.caption: psk_key_exchange_modes

url.caption: Uniform Resource Locator
url.description: The Uniform Resource Locator(URL) object describes the characteristics of a URL. Defined in RFC 1738 and by D3FEND d3f:URL.
url.name: url

hostname.description: The URL host as extracted from the URL. For example: www.example.com from www.example.com/download/trouble.

path.description: The URL path as extracted from the URL. For example: /download/trouble from www.example.com/download/trouble.

resource_type.description: The context in which a resource was retrieved in a web request.

url_string.description: The URL string. See RFC 1738. For example: http://www.example.com/download/trouble.exe. Note: The URL path should not populate the URL string.

user.caption: User
user.description: The User object describes the characteristics of a user/person or a security principal. Defined by D3FEND d3f:UserAccount.
user.name: user

account.description: The user's account or the account associated with the user.

domain.description: The domain where the user is defined. For example: the LDAP or Active Directory domain.

groups.description: The administrative groups to which the user belongs.

name.description: The username. For example, janedoe1.

org.description: Organization and org unit related to the user.

type.description: The type of the user. For example, System, AWS IAM User, etc.

1.description: Regular user account.
1.caption: User

2.description: Admin/root user account.
2.caption: Admin

3.description: System account. For example, Windows computer accounts with a trailing dollar sign ($).
3.caption: System

uid.description: The unique user identifier. For example, the Windows user SID, ActiveDirectory DN or AWS user ARN.

uid_alt.description: The alternate user identifier. For example, the Active Directory user GUID or AWS user Principal ID.

vulnerability.caption: Vulnerability Details
vulnerability.description: The Vulnerability Details object describes characteristics of an observed vulnerability.
vulnerability.name: vulnerability

vendor_name.description: The vendor who identified the vulnerability.

web_resource.caption: Web Resource
web_resource.description: The Web Resource object describes characteristics of a web resource that was affected by the activity/event.
web_resource.name: web_resource

data.description: Details of the web resource, e.g, file details, search results or application-defined resource.

name.description: The name of the web resource.

type.description: The web resource type as defined by the event source.

uid.description: The unique identifier of the web resource.

url_string.description: The URL pointing towards the source of the web resource.

categories_meta.caption: Categories
categories_meta.name: category
categories_meta.description: The OCSF categories organize event classes, each aligned with a specific domain or area of focus.

findings.caption: Findings
findings.description: Findings events report findings, detections, and possible resolutions of malware, anomalies, or other actions performed by security products.

iam.caption: Identity & Access Management
iam.description: Identity & Access Management (IAM) events relate to the supervision of the system's authentication and access control model. Examples of such events are the success or failure of authentication, granting of authority, password change, entity change, privileged use etc.

discovery.caption: Discovery
discovery.description: Discovery events report the existence and state of devices, files, configurations, processes, registry keys, and other objects.

application.caption: Application Activity
application.description: Application Activity events report detailed information about the behavior of applications and services.

dictionary.caption: Attribute Dictionary
dictionary.description: The Attribute Dictionary defines attributes and includes references to the events and objects in which they are used.
dictionary.name: dictionary

access_list.caption: Access List
access_list.description: The list of requested access rights.

access_mask.caption: Access Mask
access_mask.description: The access mask in a platform-native format.

access_result.caption: Access Check Result
access_result.description: The list of access check results.

accessed_time.caption: Accessed Time
accessed_time.description: The time when the file was last accessed.

accessor.caption: Accessor
accessor.description: The name of the user who last accessed the object.

account.caption: Account
account.description: The account object describes details about the account that was the source or target of the activity.

ack_reason.caption: Acknowledgement Reason
ack_reason.description: An integer that provides a reason code or additional information about the acknowledgment result.

ack_result.caption: Acknowledgement Result
ack_result.description: An integer that denotes the acknowledgment result of the DCE/RPC call.

activity_id.caption: Activity ID
activity_id.description: The normalized identifier of the activity that triggered the event.

99.caption: Other
99.description: The event activity is not mapped.

activity_name.caption: Activity
activity_name.description: The event activity name, as defined by the activity_id.

actor.caption: Actor
actor.description: The actor object describes details about the user/role/process that was the source of the activity.

actual_permissions.caption: Actual Permissions
actual_permissions.description: The permissions that were granted to the in a platform-native format.

alert.caption: Client TLS Alert
alert.description: The integer value of TLS alert if present. The alerts are defined in the TLS specification in RFC-2246.

algorithm.caption: Algorithm
algorithm.description: The applicable algorithm, normalized to the caption of 'algorithm_id'. See specific usage.

algorithm_id.caption: Algorithm ID
algorithm_id.description: The identifier of the normalized algorithm. See specific usage.

analytic.caption: Analytic
analytic.description: The analytic technique used to create the finding or detection

api.caption: API Details
api.description: Describes details about a typical API (Application Programming Interface) call.

app.caption: Application
app.description: The application that reported the event.

app_name.caption: Application Name
app_name.description: The name of the application that is associated with the event or object.

architecture.caption: Architecture
architecture.description: Architecture is a shorthand name describing the type of computer hardware the packaged software is meant to run on.

args.caption: HTTP Arguments
args.description: The arguments sent along with the HTTP request.

banner.caption: SMTP Banner
banner.description: The initial SMTP connection response that a messaging server receives after it connects to a email server.

attacks.caption: Attacks
attacks.description: An array of attacks associated with an event.

attributes.caption: Attributes
attributes.description: The bitmask value that represents the file attributes.

auth_protocol.caption: Auth Protocol
auth_protocol.description: The authentication protocol as defined by the caption of 'auth_protocol_id'. In the case of 'Other', it is defined by the event source.

auth_protocol_id.caption: Auth Protocol ID
auth_protocol_id.description: The normalized identifier of the authentication protocol used to create the user session.

auth_type.caption: Authentication Type
auth_type.description: The agreed upon authentication type, normalized to the caption of 'auth_type_id'. In the case of 'Other', it is defined by the event source.

auth_type_id.caption: Authentication Type ID
auth_type_id.description: The normalized identifier of the agreed upon authentication type. See specific usage.

authorizations.caption: Authorization Information
authorizations.description: This object provides details such as authorization outcome, associated policies related to activity/event.

autoscale_uid.caption: Autoscale UID
autoscale_uid.description: The unique identifier of the cloud autoscale configuration.

base_address.caption: Base Address
base_address.description: The memory address where the module was loaded.

base_score.caption: Base Score
base_score.description: The base score as reported by the event source. See specific usage.

bios_ver.caption: BIOS Version
bios_ver.description: The BIOS version. For example: LENOVO G5ETA2WW (2.62).

boundary.caption: Boundary
boundary.description:
The boundary of the connection, normalized to the caption of 'boundary_id'. In the case of 'Other', it is defined by the event source.

For cloud connections, this translates to the traffic-boundary(same VPC, through IGW, etc.). For traditional networks, this is described as Local, Internal, or External.

boundary_id.caption: Boundary ID
boundary_id.description:
The normalized identifier of the boundary of the connection.

For cloud connections, this translates to the traffic-boundary (same VPC, through IGW, etc.). For traditional networks, this is described as Local, Internal, or External.

1.caption: Localhost
1.description: Local network traffic on the same endpoint.

10.caption: Gateway VPC
10.description: Through a gateway VPC endpoint (Nitro-based instances only)

11.caption: Internet Gateway
11.description: Through an Internet gateway (Nitro-based instances only)

2.caption: Internal
2.description: Internal network traffic between two endpoints inside network.

3.caption: External
3.description: External network traffic between two endpoints on the Internet or outside the network.

4.caption: Same VPC
4.description: Through another resource in the same VPC

5.caption: Internet/VPC Gateway
5.description: Through an Internet gateway or a gateway VPC endpoint

7.caption: Intra-region VPC
7.description: Through an intra-region VPC peering connection

8.caption: Inter-region VPC
8.description: Through an inter-region VPC peering connection

bytes.caption: Total Bytes
bytes.description: The total number of bytes (in and out).

bytes_in.caption: Bytes In
bytes_in.description: The number of bytes sent from the destination to the source.

bytes_out.caption: Bytes Out
bytes_out.description: The number of bytes sent from the source to the destination.

caption.caption: Caption
caption.description: A short description or caption of the device. For example: Scanner 1 or Database Manager.

categories.caption: Website Categorization
categories.description: The Website categorization names, as defined by category_ids enum values.

category.caption: Category
category.description: The object category. See specific usage.

99.caption: Other
99.description: The Domain/URL category is not mapped. See the categories attribute, which may contain a data source specific value.

category_name.caption: Category
category_name.description: The event category name, as defined by category_uid value.

category_uid.caption: Category ID
category_uid.description: The category unique identifier of the event.

cc.caption: Cc
cc.description: The email header Cc values, as defined by RFC 5322.

certificate.caption: Certificate
certificate.description: The certificate object containing information about the digital certificate.

certificate_chain.caption: Certificate Chain
certificate_chain.description: The Chain of Certificate Serial Numbers field provides a chain of Certificate Issuer Serial Numbers leading to the Root Certificate Issuer.

chassis.caption: Chassis
chassis.description: The chassis type describes the system enclosure or physical form factor. Such as the following examples for Windows Windows Chassis Types

cis_csc.caption: CIS CSC
cis_csc.description: The CIS Critical Security Controls is a list of top 20 actions and practices an organization’s security team can take on such that cyber attacks or malware, are minimized and prevented.

class.caption: Class
class.description: The class name of the object. See specific usage.

class_name.caption: Class
class_name.description: The event class name, as defined by class_uid value.

class_uid.caption: Class ID
class_uid.description: The unique identifier of a class. A Class describes the attributes available in an event.

classification_ids.caption: Classification IDs
classification_ids.description: The list of normalized identifiers of the malware classifications. Reference: STIX Malware Types

classifications.caption: Classifications
classifications.description: The list of malware classifications, normalized to the captions of the classification_id values. In the case of 'Other', they are defined by the event source.

client_ciphers.caption: Client Cipher Suites
